Prolog has only one data type, the term, and it comes in various forms:
_ is an anonymous variable which means “any term”
Multiple occurrences of _ within a predicate definition do not necessarily represent the same value
A “functor” atom followed by arguments (also terms) in parentheses
Form compound terms that can use prefix or infix notation
[Head|Tail] unifies such that Head is 1 and Tail is [2, 3, 4]
H1 is 1, H2 is 2, and Tail is [3, 4]
The functor . of arity 2 (written as ./2) is a special syntax for denoting lists
A program describes a set of relations
A fact is a clause with an empty body
A rule is a clause with a body:
read as “Head is true if Body is true”
The body may involve conjunction, indicated with a comma between terms:
read as “Head is true if Foo and Bar are both true”
The body may involve disjunction, indicated with a semi-colon between terms:
read as “Head is true if either Foo or Bar is true”
disjunction short-circuits, so if Foo is true the Bar goal is never called
-> is a predicate that can be used as infix operator to produce “if/then” semantics
Combined with ; it resembles a the “?:” ternary operator of other languages, or an “if/then/else”
read as “if Goal1 succeeds, call Goal2; otherwise call Goal3”
, and ; and -> are examples of built-in predicates
Rule bodies always consist of calls to predicates, known as “goals”
A fact (rule clause without a body) is equivalent:
Because predicates have a relational nature, they can often be used in more than one direction
For example, the built-in append/3 predicate can be used:
true if N is the length of the list
Get the length of the list
N is now unified with the length of the list
Execution begins with a user-provided goal called a query
Under the hood, Prolog tries to find the resolution refutation of the query
If the negated query can be refuted, it follows that the query is the logical consequence of the program
In order to satisfy goals, Prolog “unifies” terms
That is, it looks for a substitution that demonstrates that two seemingly different terms are in fact identical or equal
This is Prolog’s secret sauce: you tell it the rules of a system, and it finds values that conform to those rules
What unifies with both lamb and icecream
Entering ; repeatedly will report lamb, icecream and finally no.
Goal resolution can be thought of as analogous to function calls in other languages
Except that multiple clause heads can match a given call
Prolog will backtrack to the last choice-point if a goal fails

Declarative logic programming often feels like functional programming
Partly because of the role of recursion
Partly because of the “pure” feeling of the model
The two-way nature of predicates, however, breaks with the functional model
Reminder that those aren’t function calls, even though they might resemble them
Prolog can answer hard questions easily
Syntax and basic building blocks extremely simple and quickly learned (like IO)
Strangeness compared to imperative/procedural model that we’re used to can make some things initially difficult (eg. state, tail-recursion)
Hard to reason about performance characteristics of programs when so much of how Prolog arrives at the answer seems like magic
(Evidently this isn’t a problem for a seasoned Prolog veteran.)
I knowingly tried to bash some square pegs into round holes with Prolog, hoping that I would get a feel for its true nature as I explored its limits
In the end, I feel like I only just scratched the surface
